text: 13 options trading lies that you've been told now that's a little inflammatory not all of these are directly what I would call lies but there are a lot of misrepresented data points that are super misleading to people so the goal of this video is to walk through 13 of them what they are and then to give you the reality around some of them hopefully so that you can make better trading decisions let's get straight into it so this is actually a post that I recently did on Reddit not too long ago and it serves as a great spot for us to start the conversation and I'll be able to add way more color around these obviously because we are on a video so the first one you see here is 90 of options expire worthless and the reality this is not true the overwhelming majority of options are closed before expiration 55 to 60 of the total option contracts that are opened about 30 to35 5 of those expire worthless so the reason why this matters is because sometimes when people will say like oh I like to sell options because most of them expire worthless it's not the case and it's important to differentiate that's why I highlight a lot of these it's not just because the fact in and of itself is wrong but it's the implications of what the LIE is in this context so you can look at this data um

text: option an option has two parts of the premium intrinsic and extrinsic value x trinsic value is broken off it has time which is we know time time is defined at the onset of the option time decays linearly and then there's volatility the volatility component is where there can be Edge in selling Theta or selling options for the sake of collecting Theta but the time frame that it makes sense is not always and it's actually relative to the relationship between implied and realized volatility so if we take a look at this down here you can see that there are periods where implied volatility exceeds the same time frame for realized volatility and then other times it's the inverse so in this case if you sell Theta here you actually can lose money because the realized volatility is more volatile than what's implied which is what's priced into your options when you choose to sell now a couple cliffnotes versions for General context here is if you're looking at things like spy well this very often will have risk premiums so if you take a look at this chart this is going back 6 months notice that there is this one period this was back that move during August of this year where realiz really picked up a bit compared to implied but generally speaking the indices are going to have risk premiums so it is absolutely okay and safe to assume in general you can find

text: next one you can't go broke taking profits you absolutely can and this is for a very specific reason that's pretty simple it has everything to do with expected return sooner or later risk is going to be realized what I mean by that is so we have nine winning trades one losing trade you're making 50 on each of those winning trades so it's really high win rate 90 however on that one loss if you lose 475 your gross overall expect pl here is 25 bucks you lose money so why why is that the case you can't go broke taking profits well the problem is sooner or later if you continue to trade you're going to have a loss so the only scenario where you can't go broke taking profits is if you don't have a losing trade which you're we're all going to have at some point so it's a it's a completely broken saying that forces people into something called the disposition effect which is really well studied and is where Traders have a propensity to take winning trades down too fast and let winning trades run too large and these kinds of sayings feed directly into that the way we need to manage trades is based on expected return it's not about little sayings like you can't go broke taking profit because sooner or later you're going to have losing trade which can hurt the next one buying is better than selling or selling

text: directly into that the way we need to manage trades is based on expected return it's not about little sayings like you can't go broke taking profit because sooner or later you're going to have losing trade which can hurt the next one buying is better than selling or selling is better than buying the punchline here is neither is better they both have have a use case that's really important and if one was structurally better than the other nobody would do the other there's lots of smart people in markets so they have use cases they both have pros and cons it's up to you as a Trader to determine what's better for what you're trying to do I both buy and sell it's entirely context dependent the next grouping options are zero sum so in a nutshell they absolutely are now I want to talk about what this means though because most people when they say options are zero sum it simply means that in order for one option to make money the other option on the other side is losing money this is looking at the option contracts in a vacuum and again it's completely correct the problem is the mindset that it infers against the reality the mindset it infers is that because options are zero sum it means that the counterparty on the other side of the trade is also probably sophisticated that might know more than you do and there's a reason why

text: the problem is the mindset that it infers against the reality the mindset it infers is that because options are zero sum it means that the counterparty on the other side of the trade is also probably sophisticated that might know more than you do and there's a reason why they're on on the other side of the trade that might be smarter than the reason you're getting into your trade or something along those lines the problem is multiple fold the first thing is the counterparty to your trade is probably a market maker which fun fact the market maker doesn't actually care that much about how much they're going to make on the option itself it's a bonus but they make money off of providing liquidity and capturing the bid ask spread so this is where we remove ourselves from the vacuum of just comparing options themselves and what that might infer against the reality of markets which is typically the counterparty to your trade is a market maker who's going to make money by providing liquidity the next important component is that the overall process that somebody's placing a trade for is different so for example let's go back to our example in Tesla and let's say that we have a short call well if somebody sells a call the General inference is oh they want the stock to go down right options are zero sum so that means if I'm buying a call somebody's selling the

text: go back to our example in Tesla and let's say that we have a short call well if somebody sells a call the General inference is oh they want the stock to go down right options are zero sum so that means if I'm buying a call somebody's selling the call and the person selling the call obviously wants the stock to go down maybe or maybe they have 200 shares of Tesla as part of that position and they actually want it to go up they're just collecting some premium against their long shares and they're actually bullish they might actually have the same thesis you do but they're putting a position on that might make sense for the portfolio so the reason why I call this out is because the inferences people make from it that lead them to incorrect conclusions the reality is markets are very diverse there's lots of reasons why people are doing things so if you take the inference that there Zero Sum to mean that somebody is directly opposing your idea for uh potentially better researched idea it's misleading the next one to make money you need to emulate what inst institutions do this one's pretty simple the fact of the matter is institutions are playing a completely different game than you that's what it comes down to so there are elements that an institution exhibits that are great to model things like having a rigorous process checks and balances training those kinds

text: this one's pretty simple the fact of the matter is institutions are playing a completely different game than you that's what it comes down to so there are elements that an institution exhibits that are great to model things like having a rigorous process checks and balances training those kinds of things are great but the function of a market maker is completely different you as a retail Trader are making money off of speculating a market maker makes money off of providing liquidity and managing risk literally a completely different game so when people come out and say oh my friend is a hedge fund manager or my buddy does this or I was a former whatever it's cool to have that experience but there's a reason why a lot of people that move from professional trading into retail trading don't do as well and it's because they're just different it's different games so I would think really carefully about what elements of institutional professional trading you try to pick up as a retail Trader because they're doing things differently and I actually use a very specific example here uh at the end of the post it says um taking the applicable elements is great obviously of institutional trading that makes sense but trying to emulate what they do is akin to emulating playing basketball like sha even though you're 56 right that's a it's an inherent attribute that you don't have things that market makers have access to
